byline.original: By MICHAEL CIEPLY and BROOKS BARNES

abstract: Sony Pictures chairman Michael Lynton and other studio executives are discussing proposals that could have huge effect on mission and structure of 93-year-old Motion Picture Association of America, which has been policy face for Hollywood's big movie studios; pressures at MPAA were brought into open at height of hacking crisis over Sony's film The Interview.
lead_paragraph: Proposals are being discussed that might jolt the Motion Picture Association of America, the 93-year-old policy front for Hollywood’s major studios, into line with the realities of a changing entertainment business.

headline.main: After Sony Hacking, the M.P.A.A. Considers Major Changes
